headline.main: SOVIET PRESS HINTS AT A BIGGER PLOT

results.snippet: The Soviet Union sent messages of condolence to Indian leaders today over the assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, while Soviet press accounts suggested her assassination was part of a broader conspiracy, with possible support from...
results.lead_paragraph: The Soviet Union sent messages of condolence to Indian leaders today over the assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, while Soviet press accounts suggested her assassination was part of a broader conspiracy, with possible support from abroad. The tributes, and the detailed coverage by the Soviet press agency Tass, reflected the close relations that developed between India and the Soviet Union under Mrs. Gandhi's rule. There was no immediate indication which Soviet leader would attend Mrs. Gandhi's funeral Saturday.

headline.main: DRUG MADE IN SPACE SHUTTLE IS CONTAMINATED

results.snippet: A drug manufactured in space to assure purity is contaminated and cannot be used for testing, the McDonnell Douglas Corporation says.   The company hopes some day to market the drug, a hormone, to treat diseases afflicting millions of people. For...
results.lead_paragraph: A drug manufactured in space to assure purity is contaminated and cannot be used for testing, the McDonnell Douglas Corporation says. The company hopes some day to market the drug, a hormone, to treat diseases afflicting millions of people. For proprietary reasons, it has not named the diseases or the drug.

headline.main: PHOTOGRAPHY'S NEW BAG OF TRICKS

results.snippet: Fred Ritchin, a former photo editor of The New York Times Magazine, is writing a book on contemporary photojournalism.     DISPLAYING A PHOTOgraph of Manhattan on one side of the screen and a photograph of the Statue of Liberty on the other, the...
results.lead_paragraph: Fred Ritchin, a former photo editor of The New York Times Magazine, is writing a book on contemporary photojournalism. DISPLAYING A PHOTOgraph of Manhattan on one side of the screen and a photograph of the Statue of Liberty on the other, the computer operator easily copies the tourist icon, transferring it to a patch of open space in Midtown. He softens and slightly darkens the statue's edges. An observer of the newly created photograph (shown on page 45) would wonder what the Statue of Liberty and the similarly ''relocated'' Eiffel Tower and Transamerica Pyramid were doing in Midtown Manhattan. The computer is at the heart of a revolution in image making. It is now possible not only to make almost seamless composites of existing photographs and to alter images in such a way that the changes may not be detected, but - using mathematics instead of a camera - it is possible to create images that are nearly photographic in their realism. With the last technique, it might even be possible at some future date to ''recreate'' long-dead movie stars to appear in new movies.

headline.main: SUMMARIES OF MAJOR SENATE RACES

results.snippet: Illinois PercySimon    Senator Charles H. Percy, the 65- year-old Republican, is facing Representative Paul Simon, 55, a liberal downstate Democrat. This campaign has been a different sort of test for Mr. Percy, a ''progressive'' who in three...
results.lead_paragraph: Illinois PercySimon Senator Charles H. Percy, the 65- year-old Republican, is facing Representative Paul Simon, 55, a liberal downstate Democrat. This campaign has been a different sort of test for Mr. Percy, a ''progressive'' who in three previous races has been challenged by conservatives from Chicago. This year, Mr. Percy has worked hard to win the support of the Republican right wing, tying himself closely to the economic policies of the Reagan Administration. Mr. Simon has mounted an appeal to blacks, liberal Democrats and moderate Republicans who have traditionally supported Mr. Percy. Iowa JepsenHarkin Senator Roger W. Jepsen, a 55- year-old Republican, is defending his seat against Representative Tom Harkin. Mr. Jepsen, faced with negative publicity about invoking a constitutional privilege to escape a traffic ticket and applying for membership in a ''health spa'' that was closed on prostitution charges, has depicted himself as a Senate leader and has relied upon visits by big-name Republicans. Mr. Harkin, 44, a Democrat with five terms in the House, has tried to hold the urban Democratic vote and his conservative base in western Iowa while attracting moderate Republicans and farmers. Massachusetts

headline.main: SPACE SHUTTLE POISED FOR LIFTOFF ON SATELLITE SALVAGE OPERATION

results.snippet: The space shuttle Discovery is set to begin an ambitious eight-day mission delivering two new satellites to orbit and picking up two errant satellites in the world's first space salvage operation.   The spaceship, with five astronauts aboard, is...
results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Discovery is set to begin an ambitious eight-day mission delivering two new satellites to orbit and picking up two errant satellites in the world's first space salvage operation. The spaceship, with five astronauts aboard, is scheduled for launching here at 8:22 A.M. Wednesday. The countdown proceeded smoothly today, and fair skies were forecast for liftoff time. If the Discovery gets away as planned, it will be the shortest interval, less than a month, between flights in the shuttle project. This will be the project's 14th flight and Discovery's second. A sister ship, the Challenger, landed here Oct. 13 after a seven-day flight.

headline.main: PARADE IN SOVIET MARKS REVOLUTION

results.snippet: Soviet tanks, missiles and artillery paraded through Red Square today in the annual Revolution Day ritual, but the Defense Minister, Marshal Dmitri F. Ustinov, was not there to review the display.    Soviet officials said that the 76-year- old...
results.lead_paragraph: Soviet tanks, missiles and artillery paraded through Red Square today in the annual Revolution Day ritual, but the Defense Minister, Marshal Dmitri F. Ustinov, was not there to review the display. Soviet officials said that the 76-year- old minister, who has not appeared in public since late September, was ill. In his place, Marshal Sergei L. Sokolov, a First Deputy Defense Minister, said in a keynote speech that American policy presented a threat of war and that ''we have never wavered and will never waver in the security of our country and the security of our allies.'' The troops, banners snapping in a chilly breeze, answered with three deep cries of ''Hurrah!'' that echoed off the Kremlin's red-brick wall.

headline.main: GARN, HEAD OF SENATE SPACE PANEL, IS CHOSEN TO FLY ABOARD SHUTTLE

results.snippet: Senator Jake Garn, chairman of a subcommittee that oversees space agency budgets, has accepted an invitation to become the first public official to fly in a space shuttle.   The announcement, made today by the Utah Republican and confirmed by the...

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Senator Jake Garn, chairman of a subcommittee that oversees space agency budgets, has accepted an invitation to become the first public official to fly in a space shuttle. The announcement, made today by the Utah Republican and confirmed by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, did not specify when the flight would come. There were indications that it could be as early as next May. This would put the Senator well ahead of the schoolteacher that President Reagan in August promised would be the first citizen passenger of an American spaceship.

headline.main: The Ultimate Junket NASA has invited Senator Jake Garn, the chief arbiter of its funds on the Senate Appropriations Committee, to go for a ride on the space shuttle. There've been enough astronauts sent to the Senate, so what's wrong with sending a Senator into space?

results.snippet: Exactly that. It was their careers as astronauts that gave Jack Schmitt and John Glenn entree to the Senate. If being shot into space can make a novice more electable to Congress, it will surely boost an incumbent politician into a third term and...
results.lead_paragraph: Exactly that. It was their careers as astronauts that gave Jack Schmitt and John Glenn entree to the Senate. If being shot into space can make a novice more electable to Congress, it will surely boost an incumbent politician into a third term and beyond. Senator Garn, a 52-year-old Utah Republican, must stand for re-election in 1986.

headline.main: SKETCHES OF ASTRONAUTS ON MOON

results.snippet: Anna L. Fisher    A physician . . . she has a 14-month-old- daughter, Kristin Anne, and thus is the first mother in space . . . mission specialist, scheduled to use mechanical arm to snare two failed satellites . . . fourth woman in space . . ....
results.lead_paragraph: Anna L. Fisher A physician . . . she has a 14-month-old- daughter, Kristin Anne, and thus is the first mother in space . . . mission specialist, scheduled to use mechanical arm to snare two failed satellites . . . fourth woman in space . . . husband, Dr. William Fisher, also an astronaut . . . On career and family, she says: ''You're juggling all the time. Your husband and you both have to be in tune. If it's a sacrifice at all, you sacrifice personal time. When I come home I want to spend all my time with Kristin or Bill. I used to be an avid reader and since Kristin was born I've read one book. When I use the word sacrifice that's not correct because Kristin's going to be this little for such a short period of time and I'm going to have ample time to myself and perhaps wish to have this time back.'' . . . Born in St. Albans, Queens . . . high school in San Pedro, Calif. . . . graduated cum laude in chemistry from University of California at Los Angeles in 1971 . . . spent year in graduate school in chemistry at U.C.L.A. . . . earned M.D. from there in 1976 . . . met husband in medical school . . . read of requirements for mission specialist in 1977 while intern . . . selected as astronaut in January 1978 . . . continued emergency room work in spare time in early days at NASA . . . assisted in development and testing of shuttle's mechanical arm . . . worked as physician in rescue helicopters . . . is 5 feet 4 inches tall, weighs 110 pounds.

headline.main: ANOTHER SHUFFLE IN SPACE,AND A SENATOR ON DECK

results.snippet: Two astronauts have touched down in the Senate. It looks as if Jake Garn, Republican of Utah, will be the first Senator to take off into space. Mr. Garn said last week that he had accepted an invitation from the National Aeronautics and Space...

byline.original: By Richard Levine and Katherine Roberts

results.lead_paragraph: Two astronauts have touched down in the Senate. It looks as if Jake Garn, Republican of Utah, will be the first Senator to take off into space. Mr. Garn said last week that he had accepted an invitation from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to fly on the space shuttle ''at a mutally agreeable date.'' ''I'm still pinching myself,'' said Mr. Garn, who has been jogging 20 to 25 miles a week to keep ''in physical shape so there would be no question.'' As a Navy pilot and later an Air National Guard officer, the 52- year-old Senator has logged more than 10,000 hours aloft - more than all but one astronaut. Perhaps more to the point, Mr. Garn is head of the subcommittee of the Senate Appropriations Committee that oversees NASA, and the agency will be asking Congress next year for more seed money for its $8 billion space station program and for added funds to improve the shuttle's reliability.

headline.main: CONSIDERING ERRORS, FREAKS AND ODDITIES

results.snippet: It is the hope of virtually all stamp   collectors to find that rare production error that not only leads to   riches, but maybe fame. Sometimes the finder's name ensures a place in philatelic history. But, in the 145 years of stamp collecting,...
results.lead_paragraph: It is the hope of virtually all stamp collectors to find that rare production error that not only leads to riches, but maybe fame. Sometimes the finder's name ensures a place in philatelic history. But, in the 145 years of stamp collecting, there have been relatively few such instances. Nearly a half million stamp issues have occurred since May, 1840 and untold billions of stamps printed. However, there remains an interesting aspect of the hobby that allows the pleasures of ''the search'' but more opportunity for results: freaks and oddities. Coupled with ''errors,'' freaks and oddities keep alive the stereotype of stamp collectors, who study their collection with a large magnifying glass.

headline.main: ASTRONAUTS SNARE ERRANT SATELLITE FOR THE FIRST TIME

results.snippet: Two space- walking astronauts boldly snared a satellite in orbit today and, overcoming a surprising and potentially serious obstacle, wrestled the large satellite aboard the cargo bay of the space shuttle Discovery.    It was the first salvage...

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Two space- walking astronauts boldly snared a satellite in orbit today and, overcoming a surprising and potentially serious obstacle, wrestled the large satellite aboard the cargo bay of the space shuttle Discovery. It was the first salvage operation in space. The astronauts plan to retrieve a second communications satellite Wednesday to complete one of the most ambitious and difficult operations in the shuttle's history. They are seeking to demonstrate the shuttle's overall versatility as well as to recoup some of the money insurance companies lost when the two satellites were misfired into useless orbits last February.

headline.main: SHUTTLE CREW MANEUVERS FOR ITS NEXT SALVAGE JOB

results.snippet: The Discovery astronauts, rested and confident of success, steered their spaceship today toward a second errant communication satellite, which they are to retrieve in history's first space salvage mission.   In a change of plans, one astronaut,...
results.lead_paragraph: The Discovery astronauts, rested and confident of success, steered their spaceship today toward a second errant communication satellite, which they are to retrieve in history's first space salvage mission. In a change of plans, one astronaut, Dr. Joseph P. Allen, is to stand at the end of the shuttle's mechanical arm and hold the wayward Westar 6 while the arm pulls both him and the satellite back to the shuttle's cargo bay. The Westar is almost identical to the Palapa B-2 that was salvaged Monday by Dr. Allen and Comdr. Dale A. Gardner in a six-hour spacewalk.

headline.main: SECOND SATELLITE IN SPACE RESCUED BY 2 ASTRONAUTS

results.snippet: With joyous ease and the sureness of experience, two space-walking astronauts captured a second wayward satellite today and hauled it into the cargo bay of the shuttle Discovery for the dramatic completion of the first salvage operation in space. ...

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: With joyous ease and the sureness of experience, two space-walking astronauts captured a second wayward satellite today and hauled it into the cargo bay of the shuttle Discovery for the dramatic completion of the first salvage operation in space. ''We have two satellites latched in the bay,'' Capt. Frederick H. Hauck of the Navy, the commander, radioed to Mission Control when the job was done, and a ''super job'' it was, Mission Control told the astronauts. The space shuttle Discovery, carrying the two salvaged satellites, was scheduled to end its eight-day mission with a landing Friday morning at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida. Swift, Smooth Operation The two space walkers, Dr. Joseph P. Allen and Comdr. Dale A. Gardner of the Navy, could hardly believe how much easier it was, following modified procedures, to retrieve Westar 6 than it was to haul in Palapa B-2 on Monday.

headline.main: 2 SATELLITES LAUNCHED, 2 RECAPTURED, ASTRONAUTS PREPARE FOR HOME

results.snippet: Their mission accomplished, with two new satellites delivered to orbit and two old ones salvaged, the astronauts of the space shuttle Discovery prepared today to come home to earth.    The Discovery was scheduled to land at the Kennedy Space...
results.lead_paragraph: Their mission accomplished, with two new satellites delivered to orbit and two old ones salvaged, the astronauts of the space shuttle Discovery prepared today to come home to earth. The Discovery was scheduled to land at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida at 7 A.M. Eastern time, just after sunrise. Favorable weather was predicted. The five-person crew, which flight controllers reported was in ''excellent spirits,'' spent their last full day in orbit stowing gear, concluding a scientific experiment, checking out systems, holding a space-to-ground news conference and talking by telephone with President Reagan.

headline.main: WORKING VISION OF FUTURE

results.snippet: In a week of startling images of the shuttle Discovery on a salvage mission in space, one stands out as a vision of the future: astronauts manipulating wrenches as they worked methodically in the cold void. They plucked satellites from orbit,...
results.lead_paragraph: In a week of startling images of the shuttle Discovery on a salvage mission in space, one stands out as a vision of the future: astronauts manipulating wrenches as they worked methodically in the cold void. They plucked satellites from orbit, wrestled them into the payload bay and bolted them into place. It was a mission that demonstrated the skills and daring needed for an impending era in which construction crews in spacesuits may be called on to erect platforms or stations or even whole vehicles while floating in space. This mission also highlighted a new physics of danger never faced by workers on earth.

headline.main: KARL A. SCHUON

results.snippet: Karl A. Schuon, an author who was the longtime editor of the magazine of the United States Marine Corps, died Friday at his home in Colonial Beach, Va. He would have been 71 years old on Nov. 26.
results.lead_paragraph: Karl A. Schuon, an author who was the longtime editor of the magazine of the United States Marine Corps, died Friday at his home in Colonial Beach, Va. He would have been 71 years old on Nov. 26.

headline.main: POINTS OF VIEW Of a WallOn a visit to China, Senator Jake Garn inspected the Great Wall and told his pleased hosts he looked forward to seeing it again from the space shuttle next year. Finally proving whether this is possible may be the only value of the Senator's far- fetched junket. Somehow it has become a chestnut of the space age that the Great Wall, stretching 3,750 miles, is the only man-made structure visible from space, even from the moon. The claim pops up, irrepressibly. Even this column once reported it as fact.

results.snippet: But subsequent inquiry revealed that no astronaut ever saw the wall from the moon. Buzz Aldrin ascribes the tale's origin to the pilots of Gemini flights, much closer to earth.
results.lead_paragraph: But subsequent inquiry revealed that no astronaut ever saw the wall from the moon. Buzz Aldrin ascribes the tale's origin to the pilots of Gemini flights, much closer to earth.

headline.main: Topics Points of View

results.snippet: Of a WallOn a visit to China, Senator Jake Garn inspected the Great Wall and told his pleased hosts he looked forward to seeing it again from the space shuttle next year. Finally proving whether this is possible may be the only value of the...
results.lead_paragraph: Of a WallOn a visit to China, Senator Jake Garn inspected the Great Wall and told his pleased hosts he looked forward to seeing it again from the space shuttle next year. Finally proving whether this is possible may be the only value of the Senator's far- fetched junket.

headline.main: Pete Dawkins Remembers

results.snippet: Tomorrow afternoon and evening,   the Army-Navy game and the   Heisman Trophy ceremony will be held a few hours apart. Pete Dawkins, who has since gone to Oxford, to Vietnam, to the Pentagon and to Wall Street, remembers his last Army- Navy game...
results.lead_paragraph: Tomorrow afternoon and evening, the Army-Navy game and the Heisman Trophy ceremony will be held a few hours apart. Pete Dawkins, who has since gone to Oxford, to Vietnam, to the Pentagon and to Wall Street, remembers his last Army- Navy game and his only Heisman Trophy. Dawkins is 46 years old now, so poised and so accomplished on the battlefield and in the classroom that journalists instinctively ask him about high political plans. Once known as Saint Peter at West Point because of his skills and his comportment, he is barely a year into civilian life as a securities executive after retiring as a brigadier general.
